items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
The flood risk remains.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue. River levels are high, but falling very slowly, along the River Churn, near Cerney Wick. The weather forecast is for a few showers on Thursday 1 January, Another band of  rain will pass through the area on Friday but is not expected to cause any impacts. We expect river levels to remain high but continue a slow fall over the coming days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00, midday, on the 2nd January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
The flood risk remains.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue as river levels along the River Windrush remain high, particularly in Bourton on the Water and Newbridge areas. The weather forecast is for a few showers on Thursday 1 January, Another band of rain will pass through the area on Friday but is not expected to cause any impacts. We expect river levels to remain high but continue a slow fall over the coming days.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00, midday, on the 2 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message:
Tide locking, where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible today Thursday 1 January 2026 and over the next few days. 
We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  River levels will remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message:
Tide locking, where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, this afternoon may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible Flooding is possible from 5:45pm on Thursday 1st January to 10:30pm on Friday 2nd January 2026. 
We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. River levels will remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Tide locking, where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, this afternoon may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible Flooding is possible from 4:00pm on Thursday 1st January to 11:00pm on Friday 2nd January 2026 
We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. River levels will remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 6:15pm and 8:15pm tonight, 1st January and 6:15am and 8:15am tomorrow, 2nd January. 
We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Lowestoft of 1.92mAODN at 7:15pm, on Thursday 1st January 2026, which is 1.06m above tide tables, Wind Force 8, North Westerly. Additional Flood Alert with peak level at Lowestoft of 2.03mAODN at 7:15am, on Friday 2nd January 2026, which is 1.06m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly.  The low pressure system across the North Sea will continue to keep higher than usual tides over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible 9pm and 11pm, today Thursday 1st January and 09:30am and 11:30am, tomorrow Friday 2nd January. 
Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.77mAODN at 10pm, today Thursday 1st January, which is 1.11m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, westerly. There is another peak of 2.72m at 10:30am, tomorrow Friday 2nd January, which is 0.92m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, north-westerly. Tides will remain high over the next couple of days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
High tides today may lead to flooding. 

Flooding is possible from  04:15 to 05:30 on 02/02/2026. 

Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. 

We are closely monitoring the situation . this is due to high tides and surges overtopping. 

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 

This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 9pm and 11pm tonight, 1st January and between 9:30 and 11:30 tomorrow morning, 2nd January. 
The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.77mAODN at 10pm, today Thursday 1st January, which is 1.11m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, westerly. There is another peak of 2.72m at 10:30am, tomorrow Friday 2nd January, which is 0.92m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, north-westerly. Tides will remain high over the next couple of days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High tides and forecast weather conditions may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible tomorrow 02/01/2026 between 03:15-06:30 . Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers or on the coast. We are closely monitoring the situation . Further alerts or warnings may be issued in the next few days Coastal alerts are due to overtopping as a result of tidal surge. Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded . This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Flooding is possible from 11:00PM on 01/01/2026 to 02:30AM on 02/01/2026. 
Flooding is due to a combination of high tide and wave conditions. 
Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water .

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 8:45pm and 10:45 tonight, 1st January. 
Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.75mAODN at 9:45pm, today Thursday 1st January, which is 0.99m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, westerly. The low pressure system across the North Sea will continue to keep higher than usual tides over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible from 02:15am to 06:15am on 02.01.2026.

Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at King's Lynn of 3.75mAODN at 04:15 on 02 January 2026, Wind Force 7, North Westerly. Tides will remain high over the next couple of days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid beaches and coastal promenades, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message: High tides and forecast weather conditions may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible tomorrow 02/01/2026 between 04:15-05:30. Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. We are closely monitoring the situation . Further alerts or warnings may be issued in the next few days. Coastal alerts are due to overtopping as a result of tidal surge. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are high in response to heavy rainfall earlier in December. Levels are slowly falling but remain high, and flooding of fields and roads is still possible. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 6 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bawdsey Quay and Felixstowe Ferry
items.message:
Higher than normal tides are expected to cause flooding this evening. 
Flooding is expected between 9pm and 11pm tonight, Thursday 1 January. 
Areas most at risk are Bawdsey Quay and in front of the flood defences at Felixstowe Ferry hamlet. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Harwich of 2.77mAODN at 10pm, today Thursday 1 January, which is 1.11m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, westerly. The low pressure system across the North Sea will continue to keep higher than usual tides over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this afternoon may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 6:15pm and 8:15pm on Thursday 1st January and 6:15am and 8:15am on Friday 2nd January. 
We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Lowestoft of 1.92mAODN at 7:15pm, on Thursday 1st January 2026, which is 1.06m above tide tables, Wind Force 8, North Westerly. Additional Flood Alert with peak level at Lowestoft of 2.03mAODN at 7:15am, on Friday 2nd January 2026, which is 1.06m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, Westerly. The low pressure system across the North Sea will continue to keep higher than usual tides over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message: River levels are steady but remain high. Flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. Flooding could still affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham. There is no significant rain forecast for today or tomorrow. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. People in this area should continue to monitor local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 03:00 PM on 2 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible between 6pm and 8pm tonight, 1st January and between 4:30am and 6:30am tomorrow, 2nd January. 
We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast is for a peak level at  Great Yarmouth of 1.93mAODN at 7pm, on Thursday  1 January 2026, which is 1.12m above tide tables, Wind Force 8, North Westerly. Additional Flood Alert with peak level at Great Yarmouth of 2.01mAODN at 5:30am, on Friday 2 January 2026, which is 1.19m above tide tables, Wind Force 6, North Westerly. The low pressure system across the North Sea will continue to keep higher than usual tides over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message:
Tide locking, where high tides restrict normal drainage of the river out to sea, is expected to cause flooding throughout the evening.  
Flooding is expected from 7:00pm, 1 January to 10:30am, 2 January  
Areas most at risk are in St Olaves, Somerleyton, Burgh St Peter, Oulton Broad and Beccles. Roads likely to be affected include Beccles Road at St Olaves, Geldeston Lock Lane, Gillingham Dam and Fen Lane in Beccles. River levels will remain high over the next couple of days.  
We are closely monitoring the situation .  
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals .  
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 02 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message: High groundwater levels are still expected to cause flooding. Flooding is still expected from 30th December 2025 onwards. Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbourne Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterbourne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterbourne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has fallen to 117.88m, and is expected to fall further over the next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. Roads may be damaged by floodwater. Any intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 6 January 2026, or as the situation changes.
